Award.AwardTitle: Water reorientation and proton transport at the nanoconfined water/amorphous oxide interface
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation, Professor Stephen H. Garofalini of Rutgers University addresses fundamental questions regarding proton transport at the environmentally-important hydrophilic interfaces such as between silica and nanoconfined water. There are many examples of these types of interactions in our everyday lives. These examples include: low cost water purification methods, batteries for energy storage, glasses used in touch-screen devices and solar panels, and cements and building materials. By participating in this research, graduate and undergraduate students are able to expand their education to applications in environmental chemistry using computational methods. Professor Garofalini currently works with undergraduates from underrepresented groups performing computational studies. Additional students from the University's Aresty Research Program, which provides support for undergraduates to perform research with faculty, are offered positions on this project.

The research seeks to determine the proton transfer mechanisms near interfaces as well as the structure and role of the first and second shell waters adjacent to the H3O+ ion. The roles of an amorphous silica surface structure and the higher density of water adjacent to the interface effects water reorientations and proton transfer. The as effect of nanopore size and water saturation on transport is also being studied. Using molecular dynamics computer simulations that employ reactive force fields combined with ab-initio calculations, this research provides an atomistic explanation of interactions between hydrophilic interfaces and nanoconfined water. In addition to environmental applications, the results provide a fundamental basis for further expansion into other nanoconfined solutions where the interface plays an important role. These include, enabling studies of ion transport for low cost water purification methods, ion transport in new aqueous electrolytes for energy storage, proton exchange in catalysts, stress corrosion cracking of glasses used in touch-screen devices and solar panels, and local pH on mineral growth or dissolution in cements and building materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proton transfer and hydrogen bonding processes in water and at interfaces play an important role in physical, chemical, geological, and biological sciences. Hydrogen bonds and hydrogen bond lifetimes affect proton transfers and proton conduction. Increasing proton conduction would be important in new energy applications. In highly porous materials or in nanopores, the effect of the interface between water and the containing material on proton transfer becomes extremely important. Such interfaces could alter hydrogen bonding and hydrogen bond lifetimes and proton transfer in comparison to bulk water. For instance, electrochemical studies find enhanced proton conductivity in wet mesoporous silica that has been attributed to increased formation of H3O+ ions and proton transport. However, other experiments show that interfaces with water slow hydrogen-bond reorientation times that would have a negative effect on proton transfers and conduction, potentially contradicting the electrochemical data. It can be assumed that the silica surface offset this reorientational slowing of the water molecules by providing additional transport paths for protons. However, these assumptions needed to be verified.

In order to provide an atomistic view of proton transfer mechanisms in water and at interfaces, we applied highly accurate large-scale computational simulations at the atomistic level using an equation that describes the interactions between the atoms and allows for dissociation of the molecules. Water reorientations and proton transfer in bulk water and water at the structurally heterogeneous amorphous silica (SiO2) surface at the atomistic level were evaluated. Because of the importance of the electric field in electrochemical studies of proton transport, the work was expanded to include the effects of an electric field on this interfacial behavior at planar surfaces and in nanochannels.

In pure water (without any additives), formation of the H3O+ ion requires auto-dissociation of a water molecule. Using a large system, the atomistic simulations provided us with a clear description of which protons would show auto-dissociation. Almost all dissociations were short-lived, either because of the misorientation between the reacting molecules or because of a sufficiently long-lived hydrogen bond between the resulting ions that enabled a rapid transfer of the proton back to its original oxygen, reforming the original 2 water molecules. The calculations showed that the energy barrier to recombination was extremely low and enabled easy back transfer of the proton. The results also showed the vibrational spectrum of those water molecules most prone to proton transfer, offering an experimental observable. 

As applied to the interfacial system, the dissociation and behavior of water was significantly modified due to water molecule interactions with specific structures on the heterogeneous amorphous silica surface. Results showed a significant increase in proton transfers at the interface in comparison to behavior away from the interface or in bulk water. The structure of the atoms in the glassy silica surface provided sites for hydrogen bonding that differed from hydrogen bonding sites in bulk water. This difference affected hydrogen bond lifetimes and enabled the difference in proton transfers that would be relevant to electrochemical studies.

To test the effect of electric fields on interfacial behavior, the water/silica system was exposed to weak applied electric fields in the simulations of water at planar surfaces and water in nanopores. Results enabled us to observe changes in proton transfer at and away from the interface depending upon the orientation of the weak electric field. The results of the behavior in cylindrical nanopores showed migration is highly related to the electric field orientation.

Having studied how the glass surface affects the behavior of interfacial water, a reversal idea involved studying how the water affected the glass. Whereas glass exposure to water is known to degrade glass strength, recent experiments showed that in certain processing conditions, water could be used to increase strength. However, there are two different proposed mechanisms for such behavior. Our simulations regarding each proposed mechanism provided evidence clearly supporting one mechanism as well as the flaws in the other proposed mechanism.

A graduate student and several undergraduates worked on this project, with one of the undergraduates receiving a departmental award for the research. The graduate student will defend the PhD thesis in September 2021. Research results have been presented to both undergraduate and graduate classes in the molecular behavior of glasses and classes presenting the surface properties of materials.
